title: Setup AB test with Lambda@edge function
description: I needed to A/B test two different homepage designs, and Amplify doesn't support per-branch split testing like Netlify does. Finally, I ended up using lambda@edge to set AB test, wrote the code below.

children.value: Setup AB test with Lambda@edge function
I needed to setup A/B test two different homepage designs. However Amplify doesn't support per-branch split testing like Netlify does.
Finally, I ended up using lambda@edge to set AB test, wrote the code below.
If the cookie exists, redirect proper page depending on the cookie's value so that user can see the same page as previous session.
If the cookie doesn't exist, get random variation and set cookie. Then redirect user to proper page.
Cookie should be disappeared after the experiment is done.
// Try to find the variation in the experiment cookie.
// No cookie is found, determine the variation randomly.
// At this point there's always a cookie for this experiment.
// Update the URI and return the request.

How to make debounce and throttle function
The Debounce technique allow to “group” multiple sequential calls in a single one.
Optimize the code that triggers the same API request multiple times in a short time to only do it once at the end.
event so that the callback function is executed only after the resize is complete.
Show error message after finishing typing.
The throttle technique allows you to force a function to run only once every X milliseconds. throttle guarantees the execution of the function regularly, at least every X milliseconds.

요소의 공통 조상에 이벤트 핸들러를 단 하나만 할당
해도 여러 요소를 한꺼번에 다룰 수 있는 기법.
버튼 3개가 부모 div 안에 있고, 부모 div 에만
이벤트가 바인딩 되어있다. 부모는 클릭 이벤트가 발생했을때 어떤 자식이 클릭되었는지 감지하고 해당 버튼 DOM 객체를 찾아야한다.
이것을 구현하기 위해 주의해야할 사항은 다음과 같다.
버튼이 아닌 부모 div 가 클릭되면 이벤트는 무시한다.
button 요소 안의 아이콘과 택스트가 클릭되면 해당 요소의 부모요소인 button 을 찾아야한다.
을 사용, 버튼 안의 아이콘과 택스트를 클릭해도 그 요소의 부모 button 이 이벤트의 target 이 되도록 만든다.
// e.currentTarget 은 이벤트가 지정된 부모 태그
// e.target 은 이벤트가 트리거 된 태그 (자식 부모 둘다 가능)

props.code:
<script setup>
const onClick = (e) => {
  // e.currentTarget 은 이벤트가 지정된 부모 태그
  // e.target 은 이벤트가 트리거 된 태그 (자식 부모 둘다 가능)

  if (e.currentTarget === e.target) {
    // 부모에서 트리거 된 이벤트는 무시한다.
    return;
  }

  const closestBtn = e.target.closest('button');
  
  if (closestBtn) {
    const clickedBtn = closestBtn;

    // do something
    console.log(clickedBtn)
  }
};
</script>

title: get-file-list-by-word.sh
description: Get list of file containing specific word

children.value: Get a list of filenames containing a specific word.
While traversing the json files in the folder, print out if there is a file containing "WOOL".

props.code:
# !/bin/bash
for filename in ./*.json; do
    if grep -q "WOOL" "$filename" 
    then
        echo $filename
    else
        rm -rf $filename
    fi
done

CSS transform 은 기본적으로 요소의 중간이 원점 (0,0)이다. 속성에는 다음과 같은 것들이 있다.
transform-origin 을 사용하면 transform 의 기준점을 바꿀 수 있다.
animation 은 keyframe 을 통해 여러 가지 transform의 조합이 가능하다.
css animation 으로  sprite 가 가능하다

html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}
를 설정 한다. 기본값은 auto로 내용의 길이에 따라 basis가 결정된다.
width 는 폭을 강제하지만 flex-basis 는 flex-basis 크기보다 커도 괜찮다.
flex-grow 는 숫자를 지정할 수 있는데, 이 숫자의 의미는 아이템들의
flex-basis를 제외한 여백부분을 flex-grow에 지정된 숫자의 비율
여기서 남은 공간이라는 개념이 중요하다. 아래의 사진은 child1, child2 모두 같은 flex-grow:1 이지만 child1과 child2 의 크기는 다른 것을 볼 수 있다. 하지만 남은 공간의 비율은 child1과 child2가 1:1로 같다.
flex-shrink 는 flex-grow 와 쌍을 이루는 속성으로 아이템이 flex-basis의 값보다 작아질 수 있는지를 결정한다. flex-shrink에는 숫자값이 들어가는데, 몇이든 일단 0보다 큰 값이 세팅이 되면 해당 아이템이 유연한 박스로 변하고 flex-basis보다 작아진다.
기본값이 1이기 때문에 따로 세팅하지 않아도 아이템이 flex-basis보다 작아질 수 있다.
flex-shrink를 0으로 설정하면 아이템의 크기가 flex-basis 보다 작아지지 않기 때문에
순서는 grow, shrink, basis. 2개만 작성하면 basis가 두번째. 단 축약형으로 쓸 경우 flex-grow만 명시하면 flex-basis의 기본값은 auto가 아닌 0이다.
flex 를 이용하여 폭이 3:7 비율의 레이아웃 만들기

props.code:
<svg>
    <style>
        <![CDATA[
            .some-style {
                color: blue;
            }
        ]]>
    </style>
</svg>

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
    <defs>
        <path id="text-curve" d="..."></path>
    </defs>
    <text x="20" y="50">
        <textPath href="#text-curve">
            Some text here...
        </textPath>
    </text>
</svg>

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
    <text x="20" y="50">
        Some <tspan class="highlight">text</tspan> here...
    </text>
</svg>

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
    <defs>
        <linearGradient id="linear">
            <stop offset="0%" stop-color="yellow"/>
            <stop offset="50%" stop-color="hotpink"/>
            <stop offset="100%" stop-color="deepskyblue"/>
        </linearGradient>
        <radialGradient id="radial">
            ...
        </radialGradient>
        <style>
            <![CDATA[
                .path {
                    fill: url("#linear");
                }
            ]]>
        </style>
    </defs>
    <path class="path" d="..."></path>
</svg>

description: 이진 탐색을 하기 위한 전제조건으로, 요소들이 먼저 정렬이 되어있어야 한다.

// 모든 원소가 target보다 작을때에는 n + 1 을 출력해야하므로 처음 구간을 잡을때 [0, n] 을 잡는다.
// list[m] >= target 이면서 list[m-1] < target 를 만족하는 최소 m을 찾는 문제

tell us how the function interacts with the BlockChain
: only callable from other functions inside the contract
: like private but can also be called by contracts that inherit from this one
: can only be accessed from external contracts or accounts
: can be called anywhere, both internally and externally
tell us how the function interacts with the BlockChain
view: by running the function, no data will be saved/changed
pure: not only does the function not save any data to the blockchain, but it also doesn't read any data from the blockchain
don't cost any gas to call if they're called externally from outside the contract (but they do cost gas if called internally by another function)

children.value: // Assuming `OnlineStore` points to your contract on Ethereum:
When declaring reference type variables(Array, Struct, Mapping) in Solidity, you must specify data location.
refers to the space where state variables are stored. That is, all state variables are stored in Storage. In fact, all data stored in blockchain corresponds to storage.
Memory literally means a place where
that exists only when a function call (external function call) is located. Data is copied from calldata passed as a function argument to new memory and used.
Only available for external function call parameters. The main difference between Calldata and Memory is that
Memory can be modified, but Calldata cannot be modified
, only Storage is allowed, like state variables. Bytes and string types are also treated as arrays. Therefore, the Data Location must be specified for these types too.
If you want to store reference type variables directly in the blockchain and update their values, use
If you only need to read, or do not need to update state on the blockchain, but need to modify it, use
You can save gas by using the calldata keyword as a function parameter. Therefore, unless there is a special reason, use

Ethereum is made up of nodes that all share a copy of the same data. Setting a Web3 Provider in Web3.js tells our code which node we should be talking to handle our reads and writes. It's kind of like setting the URL of the remote web server for your API calls in a traditional web app.

You could host your own Ethereum node as a provider. However, there's a third-party service that makes your life easier so you don't need to maintain your own Ethereum node in order to provide a DApp for your users — Infura.

Infura is a service that maintains a set of Ethereum nodes with a caching layer for fast reads, which you can access for free through their API. Using Infura as a provider, you can reliably send and receive messages to/from the Ethereum blockchain without needing to set up and maintain your own node.

However, since our DApp is going to be used by many users — and these users are going to WRITE to the blockchain and not just read from it — we'll need a way for these users to sign transactions with their private key.

Cryptography is complicated, so unless you're a security expert and you really know what you're doing, it's probably not a good idea to try to manage users' private keys yourself in our app's front-end.
But luckily you don't need to — there are already services that handle this for you. The most popular of these is Metamask.
Metamask is a browser extension for Chrome and Firefox that lets users

, and use these accounts to interact with websites that are using Web3.js. (If you haven't used it before, you'll definitely want to go and install it — then your browser is Web3 enabled, and you can now interact with any website that communicates with the Ethereum blockchain!).

And as a developer, if you want users to interact with your DApp through a website in their web browser (like we're doing with our CryptoZombies game), you'll definitely want to make it Metamask-compatible.

Metamask uses Infura's servers under the hood as a web3 provider, just like we did above — but it also gives the user the option to choose their own web3 provider. So by using Metamask's web3 provider, you're giving the user a choice, and it's one less thing you have to worry about in your app.
Metamask injects their web3 provider into the browser in the global JavaScript object web3. So your app can check to see if web3 exists, and if it does use web3.currentProvider as its provider.
// Checking if Web3 has been injected by the browser (Mist/MetaMask)
// Handle the case where the user doesn't have web3. Probably
// show them a message telling them to install Metamask in
// Now you can start your app & access web3js freely:
After you deploy your contract, it gets a fixed address on Ethereum where it will live forever ex:
You'll need to copy this address after deploying in order to talk to your smart contract.
. Basically it's a representation of your contracts' methods in JSON format that tells Web3.js how to format function calls in a way your contract will understand.
When you compile your contract to deploy to Ethereum, the Solidity compiler will give you the ABI, so you'll need to copy and save this in addition to the contract address.
is used for view and pure functions. It only runs on the local node, and won't create a transaction on the blockchain.
and don't change state on the blockchain. They also don't cost any gas, and the user won't be prompted to sign a transaction with MetaMask.

props.code: myContract.methods.myMethod(123).call()

children.value: will create a transaction and change data on the blockchain. You'll need to use send for any functions that aren't

sending a transaction will require the user to pay gas, and will pop up their Metamask to prompt them to sign a transaction. When we use Metamask as our web3 provider, this all happens automatically when we call send(), and we don't need to do anything special in our code.

props.code: myContract.methods.myMethod(123).send()

children.value: Getting the user's account in MetaMask

props.code: var userAccount = web3.eth.accounts[0]

children.value: is the smallest sub-unit of Ether — there are

props.code:
myContract.methods.myPayableMethod(123)
.send({ from: userAccount, value: web3js.utils.toWei("0.001", "ether") })

children.value: Note that this would trigger an alert every time ANY SomeEvent was triggered in our DApp — not just for the current user. What if we only wanted alerts for the current user?
In order to filter events and only listen for changes related to the current user, our Solidity contract would have to use the

props.code: event Transfer(address indexed _from, address indexed _to, uint256 _tokenId);

to give Solidity a time range for the event logs ("block" in this case referring to the Ethereum block number):
